title: Note on group distance magic graphs $G[C_4]$

title_detail.value: Note on group distance magic graphs $G[C_4]$

summary:
A \emph{group distance magic labeling} or a $\gr$-distance magic labeling of
a graph $G(V,E)$ with $|V | = n$ is an injection $f$ from $V$ to an Abelian
group $\gr$ of order $n$ such that the weight $w(x)=\sum_{y\in N_G(x)}f(y)$ of
every vertex $x \in V$ is equal to the same element $\mu \in \gr$, called the
magic constant. In this paper we will show that if $G$ is a graph of order
$n=2^{p}(2k+1)$ for some natural numbers $p$, $k$ such that $\deg(v)\equiv c
\imod {2^{p+1}}$ for some constant $c$ for any $v\in V(G)$, then there exists
an $\gr$-distance magic labeling for any Abelian group $\gr$ for the graph
$G[C_4]$. Moreover we prove that if $\gr$ is an arbitrary Abelian group of
order $4n$ such that $\gr \cong \zet_2 \times\zet_2 \times \gA$ for some
Abelian group $\gA$ of order $n$, then exists a $\gr$-distance magic labeling
for any graph $G[C_4]$.

summary_detail.value:
A \emph{group distance magic labeling} or a $\gr$-distance magic labeling of
a graph $G(V,E)$ with $|V | = n$ is an injection $f$ from $V$ to an Abelian
group $\gr$ of order $n$ such that the weight $w(x)=\sum_{y\in N_G(x)}f(y)$ of
every vertex $x \in V$ is equal to the same element $\mu \in \gr$, called the
magic constant. In this paper we will show that if $G$ is a graph of order
$n=2^{p}(2k+1)$ for some natural numbers $p$, $k$ such that $\deg(v)\equiv c
\imod {2^{p+1}}$ for some constant $c$ for any $v\in V(G)$, then there exists
an $\gr$-distance magic labeling for any Abelian group $\gr$ for the graph
$G[C_4]$. Moreover we prove that if $\gr$ is an arbitrary Abelian group of
order $4n$ such that $\gr \cong \zet_2 \times\zet_2 \times \gA$ for some
Abelian group $\gA$ of order $n$, then exists a $\gr$-distance magic labeling
for any graph $G[C_4]$.

author: Sylwia Cichacz
fulltext:
arXiv:1204.0705v2 [math.CO] 16 May 2012

Note on group distance magic graphs G[C4]
Sylwia Cichacz∗
Faculty of Applied Mathematics
AGH University of Science and Technology
Al. Mickiewicza 30, 30-059 Kraków, Poland

November 5, 2018

Abstract
A group distance magic labeling or a G-distance magic labeling of
a graph G(V, E) with |V | = n is an injection f fromP
V to an Abelian
group G of order n such that the weight w(x) =
y∈NG (x) f (y) of
every vertex x ∈ V is equal to the same element μ ∈ G, called the
magic constant. In this paper we will show that if G is a graph
of order n = 2p (2k + 1) for some natural numbers p, k such that
deg(v) ≡ c (mod 2p+1 ) for some constant c for any v ∈ V (G), then
there exists an G-distance magic labeling for any abelian group G for
the graph G[C4 ]. Moreover we prove that if G is an arbitrary abelian
group of order 4n such that G ∼
= Z2 × Z2 × A for some abelian group A
of order n, then exists a G-distance magic labeling for any graph G[C4 ].

Keywords: distance magic labeling, magic constant, sigma labeling, graph
labeling, abelian group
MSC: 05C78,

1

Introduction

All graphs considered in this paper are simple finite graphs. Consider a
simple graph G whose order we denote by |G| = n. Write V (G) for the
vertex set and E(G) for the edge set of a graph G. The neighborhood N (x)
∗
The author was partially supported by National Science Centre grant nr
2011/01/D/ST/04104, as well as by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education.

1

 of a vertex x is the set of vertices adjacent to x, and the degree deg(x) of x
is |N (x)|, the size of the neighborhood of x.
Let w(x) =

P

y∈NG (x) l(y)

for every x ∈ V (G).

Distance magic labeling (also called sigma labeling) of a graph
G = (V, E) of order n is a bijection l : V → {1, 2, . . . , n} with the property
that there is a positive integer k such that w(x) = k for every x ∈ V .
If a graph G admits a distance magic labeling, then we say that G is
distance magic graph ([12]). The concept of distance magic labeling has
been motivated by the construction of magic squares.
The following observations were independently proved:
Observation 1.1 ([8, 9, 10, 12]). Let G be a r-regular distance magic graph
on n vertices. Then k = r(n+1)
.
2
Observation 1.2 ([8, 9, 10, 12]). No r-regular graph with r-odd can be a
distance magic graph.
Problem of distance magic labeling of r-regular graphs was studied recently (see [2, 3, 6, 9, 11]). It is interesting that if you blow up a r-regular G
graph into some specific p-regular graph (like C4 or K 2n ), then the obtained
graph H is distance magic. More formally, we have the following definition.
Definition 1.3. Let G and H be two graphs where {x1 , x2 , . . . , xp } are vertices of G. Based upon the graph G, an isomorphic copy H j of H replaces
every vertex xj , for j = 1, 2, . . . , p in such a way that a vertex in H j is
adjacent to a vertex in H i if and only if xj xi was an edge in G. Let G[H]
denote the resulting graph.
Miller at al. [9] proved the following results.
Theorem 1.4 ([9]). The cycle Cn of length n is a distance magic graph if
and only if n = 4.
Theorem 1.5 ([9]). If r ≥ 1, n ≥ 3, G is an r-regular graph and Cn the
cycle of length n. Then G[Cn ] admits a distance magic labeling if and only
if n = 4.
Theorem 1.6 ([9]). Let G be an arbitrary regular graph. Then G[K n ] is
distance magic for any even n.
2

 The following problem was posted in [2].
Problem 1.7 ([2]). If G is non-regular graph, determine if there is a distance magic labeling of G[C4 ].
It seems to be very hard to characterize such graphs. For example
there were considered all graphs Km,n [C4 ] for 1 ≤ m < n ≤ 2700 and only
K9,21 [C4 ], K20,32 [C4 ], K428,548 [C4 ] are distance magic (see [1]).
Froncek in [5] defined the notion of group distance magic graphs, i.e. the
graphs allowing the bijective labeling of vertices with elements of an abelian
group resulting in constant sums of neighbor labels.
Definition 1.8. A group distance magic labeling or a G-distance magic
labeling of a graph G(V, E) with |V | = n is an injectionP
f from V to an
abelian group G of order n such that the weight w(x) = y∈NG (x) f (y) of
every vertex x ∈ V is equal to the same element μ ∈ G, called the magic
constant.
Obviously, every graph with n vertices and a distance magic labeling
also admits a Zn -distance magic labeling. The converse is not necessarily
true.
It was proved that Observation 1.2 is also true for G-distance magic
labeling ([4]) in case n ≡ 2( mod 4).
Observation 1.9 ([4]). Let G be a r-regular distance magic graph on n ≡ 2(
mod 4) vertices, where r is odd. There does not exists an abelian group G
of order n such that G is G-distance magic.
In this paper we will prove that if G is a graph of order n = 2p (2k + 1)
for some natural numbers p, k such that deg(v) ≡ c (mod 2p+1 ) for some
constant c for any v ∈ V (G), then there exists an G-distance magic labeling
for any abelian group G for the graph G[C4 ]. Moreover we show that if G is
an abelian group of order 4n such that G ∼
= Z2 × Z2 × A for some abelian
group A of order n, then there exists a G-distance magic labeling for any
graph G[C4 ].

2

Main results

We start with the following lemma.

3

 Lemma 2.1. Let G be a graph of order n and G be an arbitrary abelian
group of order 4n such that G ∼
= Z2p × A for p ≥ 2 and some abelian group
n
A of order 2p−2
. If deg(v) ≡ c mod 2p−1 for some constant c and any
v ∈ V (G), then there exists a G-distance magic labeling for the graph G[C4 ].
Proof. Let G has the vertex set V (G) = {x0 , x1 , . . . , xn−1 }, C4 =
v0 v1 v2 v3 v0 and H = G[C4 ].
For 0 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 and j = 0, 1, 2, 3, let vji be the vertices of H that
replace xi , 0 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 in G.
If g ∈ G, then we can write that g = (w, ai ) for w ∈ Z2p and ai ∈ A for
i = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1.
Label the vertices of H in the following way

Notice that for every i
f (v0i ) + f (v2i ) = f (v1i ) + f (v3i ) = (2p − 1, 0).
So the sum of the labels in the ith part is
f (v0i ) + f (v1i ) + f (v2i ) + f (v3i ) = (2p − 2, 0),
which is independent of i. Since c ≡ deg(v) (mod 2p−1 ) for any v ∈ V (G),
therefore, for every x ∈ V (H)
w(x) = (−2c − 1, 0).

Theorem 2.2. Let G be a graph of order n and G be an arbitrary abelian
group of order 4n such that G ∼
= Z2 × Z2 × A for some abelian group A of
order n. There exists a G-distance magic labeling for the graph G[C4 ].
Proof. Let G has the vertex set V (G) = {x0 , x1 , . . . , xn−1 } and C4 =
v0 v1 v2 v3 v0 . For 0 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 and j = 0, 1, 2, 3, let vji be the vertices of H
that replace xi , 0 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 in G.
If g ∈ G, then we can write that g = (j1 , j2 , ai ) for j1 , j2 ∈ Z2 and ai ∈ A
for i = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1.
Label the vertices of H in the following way

Notice that for every i = 0, . . . , n − 1
f (v0i ) + f (v2i ) = f (v1i ) + f (v3i ) = (1, 1, 0).
So the sum of the labels in the ith part is
f (v0i ) + f (v1i ) + f (v2i ) + f (v3i ) = (0, 0, 0),
which is independent of i. Therefore, for every x ∈ V (H),
w(x) = (1, 1, 0).

Theorem 2.3. Let G be a graph of order n and G be an abelian group of
order 4n. If n = 2p (2k + 1) for some natural numbers p, k and deg(v) ≡ c
(mod 2p+1 ) for some constant c for any v ∈ V (G), then there exists a Gdistance magic labeling for the graph G[C4 ].
Proof.
The fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups states that the finite
abelian group G can be expressed as the direct sum of cyclic subgroups of
prime-power order. This implies that G ∼
= Z2α0 × Zpα1 1 × Zpα2 2 × . . . × Zpαmm
Q
m
for some α0 > 0, where 4n = 2α0 i=1 pαi i and pi for i = 1, . . . , m are not
necessarily distinct primes.
Suppose first that G ∼
= Z2 ×Z2 ×A for some abelian group A of order n, then
we are done by Theorem 2.2. Observe now that the assumption deg(v) ≡ c
mod 2p+1 and unique decomposition of any natural number c into powers
of 2 apply that there exist constants c1 , c2 , . . . , cp such that deg(v) ≡ ci
mod 2i for i = 1, 2, . . . , p for any v ∈ V (G). Hence if G ∼
= Z2α0 × A for some
2 ≤ α0 ≤ p + 2 and some abelian group A of order 24n
α0 , then we obtain
by Lemma 2.1 that there exists a G-distance magic labeling for the graph
G[C4 ].

5

 The observation follows easily from the above Theorem 2.3, however the
below Observation 2.5 shows an infinite family of Eulerian graphs with odd
order such that none of graphs was distance magic.
Observation 2.4. Let G be a graph of odd order n and G be an abelian
group of order 4n. If G is an Eulerian graph (i.e. all vertices of the graph
G have even degrees), then there exists a G-distance magic labeling for the
graph G[C4 ].
Before we proof the Observation 2.5 we need the following definition.
t is the graph obtained by taking t > 1 copies

Observation 2.5. There does not exist a distance magic graph C4 [C4 ].
(t)

Proof. Suppose that C4 [C4 ] is a distance magic graph. It is easy to observe
that:
• l(c0 ) + l(c2 ) = l(c1 ) + l(c3 ) = ac .
• l(xi0 ) + l(xi2 ) = l(xi1 ) + l(xi3 ) = aiy for 0 ≤ i ≤ t − 1.
• l(y0i ) + l(y2i ) = l(y1i ) + l(y3i ) = aiy for 0 ≤ i ≤ t − 1.
• l(z0i ) + l(z2i ) = l(z1i ) + l(z3i ) = aiz for 0 ≤ i ≤ t − 1.
Since w(zji ) = aiy +2aix +2ac = w(yji ) = aiz +2aix +2ac we obtain that aiy =
= ai for 0 ≤ i ≤ t−1. Moreover w(xij ) = aix +4ai = w(yji ) = ai +2aix +2ac ,
hence aix = 3ai − 2ac . Furthermore w(zji ) = 7ai − 2ac = w(yjl ) = 7al − 2ac
implies that ai = al = a.
Since 7a − 2ac = ac + 4ta = k it has to be that 3ac = (7 − 4t)a and
therefore t = 1 (because ac , a > 0), a contradiction.
aiz

The following observation shows that inverse of the Theorem 2.3 is not
true:
Observation 2.6. Let Kp,q be such complete bipartite graph that p is even
and q is odd and G be an abelian group of order 4(p + q). There exists a
G-distance magic labeling for the graph G[C4 ].
6

 Proof.

= Z2 × Z2 × A for some abelian group A of order p + q, then there exists

now that G ∼
= Z4 × A for some abelian group A of order p + q. Let Kp,q has
the partition vertex sets A = {x0 , x1 , . . . , xp−1 }, B = {y 0 , y 1 , . . . , y q−1 } and

respectively) in Kp,q . If g ∈ G, then we can write that g = (j, ai ) for j ∈ Z4
